summary: This document is a set of jury instructions or focus group instructions from the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, outlining the three counts in the indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell. It details the legal elements the government must prove for each charge: conspiracy to transport minors (1994-2004), conspiracy to commit sex trafficking (2001-2004), and sex trafficking of a specific minor victim (Minor Victim-4, 2001-2004). The instructions explain the burden of proof (preponderance of the evidence for this exercise) and legal concepts like conspiracy and aiding and abetting.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with three counts related to conspiring to transport minors and sex trafficking minors between 1994 and 2004.

events.title: Conspiracy to Transport Minors
events.description: The period during which Ghislaine Maxwell is alleged to have conspired with others to transport minors in interstate/foreign commerce with the intent they engage in sexual activity.

events.title: Conspiracy to Commit Sex Trafficking
events.description: The period during which Ghislaine Maxwell is alleged to have conspired to commit sex trafficking of multiple minor victims.

events.title: Sex Trafficking of Minor Victim-4
events.description: The specific charge that Ghislaine Maxwell committed sex trafficking of an individual identified as Minor Victim-4.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell is charged with three counts: (1) conspiracy to transport minors (1994-2004), (2) conspiracy to commit sex trafficking (2001-2004), and (3) sex trafficking of Minor Victim-4 (2001-2004).
The document outlines the specific legal elements the government must prove for each charge, including knowledge of the victim's age and intent regarding sexual activity.
For the exercise described, the burden of proof is 'preponderance of the evidence' (more likely than not), not the criminal standard of 'beyond a reasonable doubt.'
Count Three (sex trafficking of Minor Victim-4) can be proven under an 'aiding and abetting' theory, where Maxwell assisted another person in committing the crime.
The charges involve allegations that the illegal acts were 'in or affecting interstate commerce,' which includes using products that traveled across state lines.
